summary: Multiple myeloma is a cancer of plasma cells, a type of white blood cell that normally produces antibodies. It is characterized by the proliferation of abnormal plasma cells, which can lead to various complications affecting bones, kidneys, blood, and the immune system. While generally incurable, it is treatable with remissions possible.
causes: Malignant transformation from monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance (MGUS)
Chromosomal translocations involving immunoglobulin heavy chain gene and oncogenes
Dysregulated methylation patterns leading to oncogene activation and tumor suppressor gene repression
Abnormal histone modifications caused by dysregulation of polycomb repressive complex 2 (PRC2)
risk_factors: Certain chemicals (aromatic hydrocarbon solvents like benzene, toluene, xylene)
Occupational exposure (firefighting, hairdressing, agricultural and industrial work)
Immunodeficiency (due to HIV/AIDS, organ transplantation, rheumatoid arthritis) for EBV association
symptoms: Loss of bowel or bladder control
Mouth symptoms (pain, numbness, swelling, jaw expansion, tooth mobility, radiolucency)
CRAB criteria (Calcium elevation, Renal insufficiency, Anemia, Bone lesions)
diagnosis: Blood tests (Complete blood count, serum protein electrophoresis, quantitative immunoglobulin measurements, serum free light chain assay, beta-2 microglobulin)
Urine tests (protein electrophoresis, Bence Jones protein detection)
Bone marrow biopsy (to assess percentage of plasma cells)
Medical imaging (skeletal survey, MRI, CT scan)
Monoclonal spike (m-spike) in serum protein electrophoresis
Bone lesions (lytic lesions, punched-out lesions, osteoporosis with compression fractures)
treatments: Chemotherapy (e.g., melphalan, prednisone, bortezomib-based regimens, lenalidomide-dexamethasone)
Targeted therapy (e.g., proteasome inhibitors, immunomodulatory agents, monoclonal antibodies)
Stem cell transplant (autologous hematopoietic stem-cell transplantation - ASCT, allogeneic stem-cell transplantation)
CAR-T cell therapy (e.g., idecabtagene vicleucel, ciltacabtagene autoleucel)
Bispecific T-cell engagers (BITE) / Bispecific antibodies (e.g., teclistamab, talquetamab)
Supportive care (red blood cell transfusions, erythropoietin)
